modules.description: This module defines layout options for displaying S-expressions, supporting single-column and two-column formats. It provides comparison, serialization, and command-line parameter parsing for these layout types. Use cases include configuring diff output formatting and handling user-specified display modes via command-line flags.

This module represents pairs of lines used in displaying differences between s-expressions, where each pair is either identical or consists of two distinct lines. It provides accessors `fst` and `snd` to retrieve the first and second lines from a pair. This structure is specifically used to format and render side-by-side comparisons in the `sexp_diff_js` library.

This module represents a single line of text with associated color information, used for rendering differences in S-expressions. It provides operations to convert the line to an S-expression, compute its length, and render its content using functions for colored and plain text. The module is used to generate display-ready output in tools like `sexp_diff_js`, where visual differentiation of S-expression structures is required.

This module defines a color type with three variants—Red, Green, and Plain—and provides functions to convert the type to S-expressions, compare values, and check equality. It is used to represent and manipulate text color information in display logic. Concrete use cases include styling differences in a diff viewer where distinct colors highlight changes.

This module defines display configuration options for diffing s-expressions, including parameters like `collapse_threshold` and `num_shown`. It supports creating and serializing these configurations, with a default preset and command-line flag parsing compatible with `man diff`. These options control how differences are presented in the output, particularly for limiting and formatting displayed changes.

This module provides a cache for memoizing intermediate results during the computation of diffs between two s-expressions. It stores mappings between nodes of the original and updated s-expressions to optimize performance. The cache is used internally by the diff algorithm to avoid redundant calculations when comparing deeply nested structures.

This module represents line pairs in a diff display, handling cases where lines are visible, hidden, or fully collapsed. It provides operations to construct, inspect, and render these line pairs, particularly supporting UI elements like expandable/collapsible sections in diff viewers. The module works directly with line pair structures and integer counts to represent hidden lines, enabling precise control over diff rendering in user interfaces.

This module configures how S-expressions are displayed, particularly for diff output. It supports layout options like single-column and two-column formats, and allows setting thresholds for collapsing unchanged lines. It is used to parse command-line flags and control the visual representation of differences in S-expressions.

This module renders S-expression diffs in various formats, including plain text and ANSI-colored output. It supports two-column layouts and customizable line formatting through functions like `display_as_string_with_custom_formatting`. Use cases include generating human-readable diff output for test failures or version comparisons with visual cues for changes.

This module represents and manipulates S-expression-based diffs, supporting operations like adding, deleting, replacing, or enclosing sexps. It provides functions to apply diffs to sexps, invert diffs, and compare or hash them. Use cases include tracking and applying structured changes to S-expressions, such as in configuration management or versioned data transformations.

This module provides functions to generate and manipulate display-ready representations of S-expression diffs, including colored lines, line pairs, and collapsible sections. It works with structured types like `Line`, `Line_pair`, and `Hideable_line_pair` to model diff output, and supports configuration via `Display_options`. Concrete use cases include rendering side-by-side comparisons and interactive diff views in tools like `sexp_diff_js`, where visual clarity and user interaction are critical.

This module computes diffs between two S-expressions, identifying insertions, deletions, and modifications at any depth in the tree structure. It operates directly on `Core.Sexp.t` values without serialization, preserving structural context for more accurate comparisons. It is suitable for comparing structured data representations, such as configuration files or serialized OCaml values, where changes need to be precisely located within a nested hierarchy.

This module computes and manipulates structural diffs between S-expressions, identifying insertions, deletions, and modifications at any depth. It works directly with `Core.Sexp.t` values, supporting operations to apply, invert, and display diffs with customizable formatting. Use cases include comparing and visualizing changes in structured data such as configuration files, serialized OCaml values, and versioned documents with nested hierarchies.
